<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDelay_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDelay_Impl(uint32 millisecond)
{
    struct timespec sleep_end;
    int             status;

    clock_gettime(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, &sleep_end);
    sleep_end.tv_sec += millisecond / 1000;
    sleep_end.tv_nsec += 1000000 * (millisecond % 1000);

    if (sleep_end.tv_nsec >= 1000000000)
    {
        sleep_end.tv_nsec -= 1000000000;
        ++sleep_end.tv_sec;
    }

    do
    {
        status = clock_nanosleep(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, TIMER_ABSTIME, &sleep_end, NULL);
    } while (status == EINTR);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }
    else
    {
        return OS_SUCCESS;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
do
    {
        status = clock_nanosleep(CLOCK_MONOTONIC, TIMER_ABSTIME, &sleep_end, NULL);
    } while (status == EINTR);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the controlling expression (status == EINTR) depends on 'status' which is assigned inside the do-while body by clock_nanosleep, so it is not invariant. The do-while ensures 'status' is initialized before the test; this is a valid retry loop and does not breach Rule 14.3.
